head.title: Limiting Soft Money Would Stifle Free Speech; Globalization Threat

hedline.hl1: Limiting Soft Money Would Stifle Free Speech; Globalization Threat

abstract.p: Letter from Paul W Rosenberger supports campaign finance reform, especially now that globalization of corporations has raised specter of foreign corporate entities dominating American political process (S)

block.p: Re ''A Triumph for Campaign Reform'' (editorial, Aug. 4): Campaign finance reform is at the heart of efforts to restore credibility to the American political process and return control of this process to the citizens, where it belongs. It is the excessive influence of corporations and other monied interest groups that has disenfranchised the average American and prevented reasoned debate on a variety of critical issues, from health care to global warming.

Re ''A Triumph for Campaign Reform'' (editorial, Aug. 4): Campaign finance reform is at the heart of efforts to restore credibility to the American political process and return control of this process to the citizens, where it belongs. It is the excessive influence of corporations and other monied interest groups that has disenfranchised the average American and prevented reasoned debate on a variety of critical issues, from health care to global warming.

Deplorable as these developments are, the danger to the United States is heightened by the globalization of corporations. This development raises the specter not only of American but of foreign corporate entities' dominance of the American political process.
PAUL W. ROSENBERGER Manhattan Beach, Calif. Aug. 4, 1998
